stem: The nurse is reviewing the electronic health record (EHR) of four different patients. Based on the provided information, indicate which screening each patient requires.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
14:00 SBAR for Patient A: 68-year-old male, PMH: HTN, hyperlipidemia, smoker (40 pack-years). No recent health screenings. Reports occasional heartburn. 

14:15 SBAR for Patient B: 52-year-old female, PMH: none, mother had breast cancer at age 60. Last mammogram 2 years ago. Reports no concerns.

14:30 SBAR for Patient C: 45-year-old male, PMH: obesity, sedentary lifestyle, family history of colon cancer. No recent colonoscopy. Reports occasional constipation.

14:45 SBAR for Patient D: 28-year-old female, sexually active, no pregnancies, inconsistent condom use. No recent pap smear. Reports no concerns. 

15:00 SBAR for Patient E: 70-year-old female, PMH: Osteoporosis, COPD, never smoked. Last bone density scan 3 years ago. Reports stable condition.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
Patient A: Lipid panel pending.
Patient B: All labs within normal limits.
Patient C: All labs within normal limits.
Patient D: All labs within normal limits.
Patient E: Vitamin D level: 20 ng/mL (Low).

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Patient A: General: Overweight male. Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Patient B: General: Well-appearing female. Breast Exam: No palpable masses.
Patient C: General: Obese male. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present in all quadrants.
Patient D: General: Well-appearing female. No acute distress.
Patient E: General: Frail appearing female. Musculoskeletal: Kyphosis noted.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Patient A: Monitor BP, encourage smoking cessation, diet and exercise education.
Patient B: Continue annual physical exams.
Patient C: Encourage weight loss, increase physical activity, dietary modifications.
Patient D: Education on safe sex practices.
Patient E: Fall risk precautions, encourage weight bearing exercises.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Patient A: Lisinopril 20mg daily, Atorvastatin 40mg daily.
Patient B: None.
Patient C: None.
Patient D: None.
Patient E: Alendronate 70mg weekly, Vitamin D 2000 units daily.

rows.text: Patient A: 68-year-old male, smoker, HTN, hyperlipidemia.
Patient B: 52-year-old female, family history of breast cancer.
Patient C: 45-year-old male, obese, family history of colon cancer.

rationale.correct: The correct answers align patient risk factors and demographics with recommended screening guidelines. Regular screening is crucial for early detection and prevention of disease.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a misunderstanding of recommended screening guidelines based on patient risk factors and demographics.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient A: 68-year-old male, smoker, HTN, hyperlipidemia requires a Lung Cancer Screening.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Due to his age and smoking history, Patient A is at high risk for lung cancer and requires annual screening.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient B: 52-year-old female, family history of breast cancer requires a Mammogram.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Patient B has a family history of breast cancer, increasing her risk and requiring regular mammogram screening. Current guidelines recommend annual mammograms starting at age 40 for women with increased risk factors.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient C: 45-year-old male, obese, family history of colon cancer requires a Colonoscopy.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Due to his obesity and family history of colon cancer, Patient C requires a colonoscopy to screen for colorectal cancer. Guidelines suggest starting screening at age 45 for individuals with increased risk.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient D: 28-year-old female, sexually active requires a Pap Smear.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Patient D requires a Pap smear to screen for cervical cancer, as she is sexually active. Guidelines recommend Pap smears starting at age 21.

answerBreakdown.text: Patient E: 70-year-old female, osteoporosis requires a Bone Density Scan.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Patient E requires a bone density scan to monitor the progression of osteoporosis. Guidelines recommend bone density scans every 1-2 years for women with osteoporosis or risk factors.

clinicalPearls: Screening guidelines vary based on age, sex, family history, and lifestyle factors.
Nurses play a crucial role in educating patients about recommended screenings and promoting preventive care.
Early detection of diseases through screening improves treatment outcomes and reduces mortality.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing patient risk factors with specific screening recommendations.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully analyze each patient's demographics, medical history, and lifestyle to determine the most appropriate screening test. Refer to current screening guidelines.

mnemonic.title: SCREEN
mnemonic.expansion: Smoking (Lung Cancer), Cancer Family Hx (Colon/Breast), Reproductive Health (Pap Smear), Elderly (Bone Density), Examine Risk Factors, Next Steps (Schedule)
